title: Hugh McLeod (rugby union)
text:
Hugh Ferns McLeod <a href="Order%20of%20the%20British%20Empire">OBE</a> (8 June 1932 – 12 May 2014) was a Scottish rugby union player, who played forty times for <a href="Scotland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland</a> between 1954 and 1962. He played 14 times for the <a href="Barbarian%20F.C.">Barbarians</a> between 1954 and 1959, scoring only once, a try in their 1958 match against <a href="East%20Africa%20rugby%20union%20team">East Africa</a> in <a href="Nairobi">Nairobi</a> on 28 May 1958 (though this is erroneously listed on the Barbarian website as earning 5 points whereas a try was only worth 3 points at the time). His home team was <a href="Hawick%20RFC">Hawick RFC</a>. giving rise to his nickname, the Hawick Hardman. <a href="Allan%20Massie">Allan Massie</a> describes him as "Hawick through and through, and is indeed now President of the Club".
International career.
Hugh McLeod propped alongside <a href="Tom%20Elliot">Tom Elliot</a> of <a href="Gala%20RFC">Gala RFC</a> and <a href="David%20Rollo%20%28rugby%20union%29">David Rollo</a> of <a href="Howe%20of%20Fife%20RFC">Howe of Fife RFC</a>. He was only twenty one when he first played for Scotland, a young age at the time, and retired from international rugby at thirty. He was made pack leader for a while, and the story goes that some of the posher, or anglified players could not actually understand his accent; one of his semi-humorous phrases as pack leader was "Come here, my wee disciples."
In 1955 he took part in the <a href="1955%20British%20Lions%20tour%20to%20South%20Africa">British Lions tour of South Africa</a> and afterwards published his diary of the tour ("Hugh McLeod Diary - The British Lions Rugby Tour of South Africa 1955"). In 1959 he played on the <a href="1959%20British%20Lions%20tour%20to%20Australia%20and%20New%20Zealand">1959 British Lions tour to Australia and New Zealand</a>.

Allan Massie is equally flattering:
He was a personal friend of <a href="Bill%20McLaren">Bill McLaren</a>, also from <a href="Hawick">Hawick</a>, who describes him as "A man for whom I always have had the highest respect and admiration."
One of the Anglo-Scots is supposed to have said, "Well, I didn't understand a word of that but it all sounded damned impressive.".
Another famous story involving McLeod, and the lock <a href="Frans%20ten%20Bos">Frans ten Bos</a> and is told by <a href="Bill%20McLaren">Bill McLaren</a>. On the evening before the 1963 game between and at <a href="Stade%20Olympique%20Yves-du-Manoir">Colombes</a> in <a href="Paris">Paris</a>, Hugh McLeod and Bill McLaren were out having a meal together and bumped into ten Bos near a cafe. Hugh McLeod took Ten Bos aside, and told him bluntly:
Ten Bos tapped McLaren on the shoulder as they left the cafe, and said, "You know, I'd follow him anywhere."
Scotland later won the game 11-6, rare for an away game.
McLeod retired after forty caps, "because forty is a nice roond figure." McLeod's hobby in later life has been dog shows mainly using his bulldog Spike. He died at the age of 81 on 12 May 2014.
